0: Outside Triad Middle School, Bethany Thompson hopped on the school bus Oct. 19 with a consuming darkness shared only with her friend. "She told her she loved her and that she was her best friend forever, but that she was going to kill herself when she got home," said Wendy Feucht, 34, Bethany's mother. The short trip to her home in Cable in rural Champaign County would be the 11-year-old's last. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Shortly after stepping off the bus, Bethany went inside and found a loaded handgun on an upper shelf, her father, Paul Thompson of Dublin, learned. Instead of playing with her cats and dogs or visiting with her pet snakes, she went to the back porch and shot herself. It was unclear who owns the gun. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The tragedy could have been prevented, said Thompson, 37, who buried Bethany on Monday and now is helping prepare fundraisers to help needy kids. He wants to know whether bullying at school might have contributed to his daughter�s death. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �She was my baby girl. Everybody knew she was my princess. And she was a spoiled one,� said Thompson, who is divorced from Feucht, who had custody of the girl. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �I think that she was just done. She didn�t feel like anybody could do anything to help her,� she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �People need to know that even the littlest things can break someone.� NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Thompson had planned to pick up Bethany on Thursday the 20th for a trip to Benny�s Pizza in Marysville. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �She was all excited about it,� he recalled of the conversation the day before her death. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kids in the fifth-through-eighth-grade school noticed, said Thompson. Some picked on her. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �I think that�s why she took (her life),� Thompson said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Monday, several parents raised concerns and wanted answers about Bethany and other allegations of bullying at Triad. Four years ago, a 12-year-old boy also took his life. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Superintendent Chris Piper couldn�t answer all their questions, citing student privacy laws. But he has been meeting individually with parents. He is trying not to speculate about what caused Bethany to feel hopeless. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �Suicide is a complicated act. We�re trying to find the cause,� Piper said. �And there�s no single thing that says this is what led to it.� NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Piper acknowledged bullying behavior against Bethany last year, declining to provide details. But the matter was resolved, he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR �There was no evidence of a pattern of bullying this year,� he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Piper said efforts are underway at Triad �to change the school climate ... and re-evaluate our anti-bullying educational side so that we are able to determine when things go from normal misbehavior to a pattern of bullying and to deter and stop misbehavior.� NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Teachers, students and others in the North Lewisburg school already are asking questions.
